paper_abstract: Informally stated, we present here a randomized algorithm that given black-box access to the polynomial f computed by an unknown/hidden arithmetic formula I center dot reconstructs, on the average, an equivalent or smaller formula in time polynomial in the size of its output . Specifically, we consider arithmetic formulas wherein the underlying tree is a complete binary tree, the leaf nodes are labeled by affine forms (i.e., degree one polynomials) over the input variables and where the internal nodes consist of alternating layers of addition and multiplication gates. We call these alternating normal form (ANF) formulas. If a polynomial f can be computed by an arithmetic formula mu of size s, it can also be computed by an ANF formula I center dot, possibly of slightly larger size s (O(1)). Our algorithm gets as input black-box access to the output polynomial f (i.e., for any point x in the domain, it can query the black box and obtain f(x) in one step) of a random ANF formula I center dot of size s (wherein the coefficients of the affine forms in the leaf nodes of I center dot are chosen independently and uniformly at random from a large enough subset of the underlying field). With high probability (over the choice of coefficients in the leaf nodes), the algorithm efficiently (i.e., in time s (O(1))) computes an ANF formula of size s computing f. This then is the strongest model of arithmetic computation for which a reconstruction algorithm is presently known, albeit efficient in a distributional sense rather than in the worst case.
paper_title: Random arithmetic formulas can be reconstructed efficiently
